articles.headline: A Blank Check for Cleaning Up Madoff’s Mess
articles.snippet: The officials investigating the Ponzi scheme of Bernard L. Madoff don’t have the usual limitations. They have spent $228.3 million so far and expect to spend $1.1 billion more.
articles.abstract: The officials investigating the Ponzi scheme of Bernard L. Madoff don’t have the usual limitations. They have spent $228.3 million so far and expect to spend $1.1 billion more.
articles.lead_paragraph: Financial frauds tend to follow predictable paths after they are uncovered. At first, there is outrage and a determination to find and punish the villains. But passions fade and investigations run into ambiguities.

articles.headline: Boeing Wins Contract to Build Air Force Tankers
articles.snippet: Boeing received a $35 billion contract even though it and its supporters had seemed to assume the European builder of Airbus planes would win.
articles.abstract: Boeing received a $35 billion contract even though it and its supporters had seemed to assume the European builder of Airbus planes would win.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a surprise twist to a long-running saga, the Air Force said on Thursday that it would award a $35 billion contract for aerial fueling tankers to Boeing rather than to a European company that builds Airbus planes.

articles.headline: Hoping to Lead Bank, Italian Faces Hurdles
articles.snippet: Though qualified, Mario Draghi of Italy makes France and Germany nervous as he campaigns to become the next head of the European Central Bank.
articles.abstract: Though qualified, Mario Draghi of Italy makes France and Germany nervous as he campaigns to become the next head of the European Central Bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — He is a familiar face at the European Central Bank. Many economists think he should be the next person to run it.
articles.byline: By Liz Alderman and Jack Ewing

articles.headline: Rising Oil Prices Pose New Threat to U.S. Economy
articles.snippet: Economists say even if oil prices don’t rise further, uncertainty over the stability of the Middle East could drag down growth.
articles.abstract: Economists say even if oil prices don’t rise further, uncertainty over the stability of the Middle East could drag down growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by Motoko Rich, Catherine Rampell and David Streitfeld.
articles.byline: By Motoko Rich, Catherine Rampell and David Streitfeld

articles.headline: U.S. Pulling Back in Afghan Valley It Called Vital to War
articles.snippet: American officials say the Pech Valley consumed resources disproportionate with its importance and there are not enough troops to win decisively against the Taliban and Al Qaeda.
articles.abstract: American officials say the Pech Valley consumed resources disproportionate with its importance and there are not enough troops to win decisively against the Taliban and Al Qaeda.
articles.lead_paragraph: This article is by C. J. Chivers, Alissa J. Rubin and Wesley Morgan.
articles.byline: By C. J. Chivers, Alissa J. Rubin and Wesley Morgan

articles.headline: U.S. Trying to Pick Winners in New Mideast
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has come to a stark recognition: the region’s monarchs are likely to survive; its presidents are more likely to fall.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has come to a stark recognition: the region’s monarchs are likely to survive; its presidents are more likely to fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As the Obama administration grapples with a cascade of uprisings in the Middle East, it has come to a stark recognition: the region’s monarchs are likely to survive; its presidents are more likely to fall.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Qaddafi Forces Violently Quell Capital Protest
articles.snippet: The bloodshed heightened a standoff that has pitted Colonel Qaddafi against a spreading rebel force and increasingly alarmed international community.
articles.abstract: The bloodshed heightened a standoff that has pitted Colonel Qaddafi against a spreading rebel force and increasingly alarmed international community.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya  Mercenaries and army forces put down an attempt by protesters on Friday to break Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi’s hold on this capital city, opening fire on crowds who had taken to the streets after prayers to mount their first major challenge to the government’s crackdown, witnesses said.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Kareem Fahim

articles.headline: Air Force’s Shifting Rules Helped Boeing
articles.snippet: Aviation analysts say Boeing won a rematch for the airborne refueling tanker this week because the government put more emphasis on long-term costs.
articles.abstract: Aviation analysts say Boeing won a rematch for the airborne refueling tanker this week because the government put more emphasis on long-term costs.
articles.lead_paragraph: When a European company offered a larger tanker than Boeing for a lower price in 2008, the Air Force grabbed what seemed like a bargain.
